deliberation: Checked the verse for imagery beyond the historical-prophetic naming of Ephraim/Israel/Judah. The expression 'surrounds me with deceit' uses spatial/military language for moral-religious behavior, which is a clear metaphor, possibly with mild personification of 'deceit.' The rest is primarily theological description with textual difficulties, so I identified one main figurative expression.

instances.hebrew_text: סְבָבֻנִי בְכַחַשׁ אֶפְרַיִם וּבְמִרְמָה בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: Ephraim surrounds Me with deceit, the House of Israel with guile.
target: moral-religious conduct of the northern kingdom
vehicle: an enemy army or hostile force encircling someone
ground: hostility, pressure, and inescapable treachery
quality of the relationship (oppressive, hostile, all‑around)
the seriousness and totality of Israel’s unfaithfulness
instances.explanation: Israel’s deceit is pictured as if it were an encircling force hemming God in, using the language of physical/military surrounding to convey pervasive, hostile treachery. Deceit itself is implicitly personified as something that can ‘surround.’

deliberation: Looked for vivid imagery. The parallel phrases 'tends the wind' and 'pursues the east wind' are classic metaphors of futility and self-destructive policy. 'All day' functions as prophetic hyperbole for continual practice. The covenant with Assyria and oil to Egypt are literal political acts described without imagery.

target: Ephraim’s pursuit of foreign alliances and idolatrous policies
life of the northern kingdom under judgment
vehicle: impossible pastoral activity on something insubstantial
ground: futility and lack of substance or benefit
evaluation of outcome (useless, non‑nourishing)
the emptiness of unfaithful policy versus true reliance on God
instances.explanation: Ephraim’s political and religious maneuvers are likened to a shepherd trying to care for the wind—an absurd, pointless activity—emphasizing their complete futility.

target: Ephraim’s relentless chase after destructive, empty advantages
Israel’s national policy and spiritual direction
vehicle: chasing the east wind (קָדִים, hot desert wind)
pursuit of a violent, destructive, and uncontrollable force
ground: self-destructive, uncontrollable, and unattainable pursuit
assessment of consequences (harmful, futile)
the ruinous result of trusting in oppressive empires and idols
posture: negative evaluation of the object of pursuit
instances.explanation: By portraying Ephraim as one who runs after the scorching east wind, Hosea depicts their policies as a mad chase after something both impossible to grasp and inherently destructive.

instances.english_text: all day he is forever adding illusion to calamity
target: the frequency and persistence of Ephraim’s deceit and violence
ground: very frequent, habitual practice (not literally every minute)
intensity and pervasiveness of wrongdoing
the normality of deceit and oppression in society
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘all day’ exaggerates for effect, depicting Ephraim’s production of lies and violence as incessant, emphasizing how pervasive and habitual these sins have become.

deliberation: Examined whether references to Judah and Jacob are purely historical or figurative. The main figurative element is the legal imagery: YHWH having a 'rîb' (lawsuit) with Judah, casting the divine-human conflict in courtroom terms. The repayment language is conventional covenant-retribution language rather than a new metaphor.

instances.english_text: The LORD has a case (lawsuit) against Judah
target: the covenant relationship between God and His people
vehicle: a legal lawsuit or court case
ground: formal accusation, evidence, and just recompense
structured, adjudicated conflict
the idea that covenant violations are legally actionable before God
instances.explanation: Hosea casts God’s dealings with Judah in terms of a courtroom lawsuit, using human legal procedure as a metaphor for the covenantal judgment YHWH brings.

deliberation: This verse recalls historical episodes: Jacob’s grasping/supplanting in the womb and his later struggle with God. These are narrative allusions to Genesis rather than newly created images in Hosea. They function typologically and theologically, but the wording itself is straightforward recounting of those events, not fresh metaphor, simile, or other figure in this verse.

Continues the retelling of the Jacob story: striving with the angel, prevailing, weeping, pleading, meeting at Bethel. These are references to concrete narrative events in Genesis 32–35. No new metaphor or simile is introduced in Hosea’s wording here; the ‘speaking with us’ is theological solidarity rather than a linguistic trope. Thus no distinct figurative expression is isolated.

The verse piles up divine titles and states that ‘YHWH is His remembrance/name.’ This is standard theological diction. While ‘remembrance’ can function metonymically for God’s name as invoked in worship, here it is more a definitional statement than a figurative picture. No developed metaphor, simile, or personification appears.

Looked for imagery in the call to repentance. The key verb שוב (“return”) is classic covenantal metaphor for repentance, depicting spiritual change as spatial movement back to God. ‘Keep kindness and justice’ and ‘wait for your God’ are exhortations without additional imagery.

instances.english_text: But you, you must return to your God
target: the people’s need for repentance and renewed loyalty
vehicle: spatial movement back to a prior place/relationship
ordinary physical movement in geographic space
ground: restoration of proximity and relationship after estrangement
reversal of previous departure or wandering
the shift from alienation to renewed fellowship with God
instances.explanation: Repentance is depicted as physically returning to God, using spatial language for a moral and relational turning back, a standard Hebrew idiom and metaphor for conversion.

deliberation: The verse describes a dishonest trader with false balances. The word כְנַעַן can mean both ‘Canaanite’ and ‘merchant’; here it functions as a label for a merchant type rather than ethnicity, a metonymic usage. The balances and love of oppression are literal description of economic injustice.

instances.english_text: A Canaanite—with false balances in his hand
vehicle: ethnic label used for occupational type
ground: association of Canaanites/Phoenicians with trade and, by stereotype, sharp dealing
shared traits of commercial activity and suspected greed
the perceived moral character of certain traders
instances.explanation: The term ‘Canaanite’ is used not primarily ethnically but as a stereotypical label for a merchant, so that ‘Canaanite’ stands metonymically for ‘trader,’ highlighting the predatory character of those merchants.

deliberation: This verse quotes Ephraim’s self-assessment about being rich and guiltless. In context, Hosea is condemning Ephraim’s sin, so the boast is sharply at odds with reality. This creates prophetic irony: the character’s confident speech is meant to be understood by the audience as self-deceived and false.

instances.hebrew_text: אַךְ עָשַׁרְתִּי מָצָאתִי אוֹן לִי כׇּל־יְגִיעַי לֹא יִמְצְאוּ־לִי עָוֹן אֲשֶׁר־חֵטְא
instances.english_text: Ah, I have become rich; I have gotten power! All my gains do not amount to an offense that is real guilt.
target: the nation’s true guilt status before God
vehicle: boastful denial of any discoverable guilt
self-justifying legal language (‘they will not find in me iniquity’)
ground: contrast between self-perception and divine assessment
the idea that wealth is (wrongly) taken as proof of innocence
the blindness and arrogance of the sinner
posture: judgmental narrative framing of Ephraim’s words
instances.explanation: Hosea quotes Ephraim’s confident claim of wealth and innocence so that the audience, knowing the prophet’s accusations, recognizes this speech as deluded. The sweeping claim that no guilt can be found is hyperbolic self-justification and functions as irony in the prophetic context.

deliberation: Focused on ‘I will make you dwell in tents like the days of the festival.’ The image of dwelling in tents recalls wilderness and the Feast of Booths, and the כ-prefix marks a simile. It uses a concrete picture of tent-dwelling to describe a future state analogous to those former festive days, whether of judgment or restoration.

instances.english_text: I will let you dwell in your tents again as in the days of old (as in the days of the appointed feast).
target: Israel’s future experience under God’s dealings
vehicle: dwelling in tents like during festival days (e.g., Sukkot)
temporary, pilgrim-like living in booths during appointed times
ground: analogy between upcoming experience and earlier tent-dwelling period
themes of dependence, transience, and liturgical recollection
either disciplinary re-wildernessing or renewed festal fellowship with God
posture: solemn yet hopeful promise/threat (ambiguous in tone)
didactic reminder of past relationship patterns
instances.explanation: God depicts the future as a return to ‘dwelling in tents’ like in festal days, using the concrete image of booths to liken the coming experience to Israel’s earlier, formative times of dependence and special observance.

deliberation: The verse is meta-linguistic, speaking about God’s use of prophets, visions, and parables. The phrase ‘by the hand of the prophets’ uses ‘hand’ as a metonym for agency or instrumentality. The rest is literal description of prophetic media, even though it references parabolic/figurative speech more generally.

instances.english_text: and through the hand of the prophets I spoke in parables.
target: God’s use of prophets as His instruments
ground: the hand is what acts/works, so it represents the agent’s effective role
prophets function as God’s implementing agents in speech
emphasis on mediated, instrumental communication
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘by the hand of the prophets’ uses ‘hand’ metonymically and idiomatically for human agency, saying that God carried out His parabolic speaking through the active instrumentality of the prophets.

deliberation: Noted two figures: (1) ‘Gilead is iniquity’ where the place name stands for its inhabitants and moral character (metonymy), and (2) the explicit simile comparing their altars to stone heaps on field furrows, a striking depreciation image.

instances.english_text: As for Gilead, it is worthlessness; surely they have been in vain.
target: the people and cult of Gilead
vehicle: place-name used for its population and moral status
ground: close association between land and its inhabitants
Gilead’s identity defined by its iniquity and emptiness
the moral characterization of a region by its practices
posture: prophetic denunciation of a cult center/region
instances.explanation: The name ‘Gilead’ stands metonymically for its people and cultic life, so that the region itself is labeled ‘iniquity’ and ‘vanity,’ emphasizing how pervasively corruption defines it.

instances.hebrew_text: גַּם מִזְבְּחוֹתָם כְּגַלִּים עַל תַּלְמֵי שָׂדָי
instances.english_text: Their altars are also like stone heaps upon a plowed field.
target: the status and value of Israel’s illicit altars
cultic structures and their religious significance
vehicle: stone heaps lying on field furrows
random, obstructive piles of stones in an agricultural field
ground: uselessness, disorder, and obstruction rather than fruitful cultivation
visual resemblance of many altars to scattered mounds
the worthlessness and destructive impact of the altars
instances.explanation: By directly comparing their many altars to stone heaps strewn over plowed fields, Hosea depicts the altars as ugly, useless clutter that prevents the land from being fruitful, underscoring the futility and harm of their worship.

deliberation: This verse recounts Jacob’s historical flight to Aram and his service for a wife. ‘Israel’ here is simply Jacob under his later name; the shepherding is literal within the story. No distinctive metaphor, simile, or other figure is introduced by Hosea’s wording in this verse.

States that by a prophet YHWH brought Israel up from Egypt and by a prophet Israel was guarded. These are theological-historical assertions using straightforward causal language. Although ‘by a prophet’ expresses agency, it is not figurative; Egypt is literal. No clear metaphor, simile, or similar device is added in this line.

Searched for idioms and retributive imagery. Found (1) ‘his bloods will be upon him’—an idiomatic/metonymic way to speak of bloodguilt resting on a person, and (2) ‘his Lord will return his reproach to him’—a retributive metaphor of handing back the insult as if it were an object.

instances.english_text: And his bloods shall be cast upon him
target: Ephraim’s guilt and responsibility for bloodshed
the northern kingdom’s standing under divine justice
vehicle: physical bloodshed as a burden clinging to a person
ground: association of blood with guilt and defilement in biblical law
the idea that guilt adheres and cannot be shrugged off
inescapable accountability for violent deeds
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘his bloods shall be upon him’ uses ‘bloods’ metonymically for bloodguilt, picturing guilt as something that remains on or is thrown back onto the offender, emphasizing inescapable responsibility.

instances.english_text: and his Lord will return his reproach to him.
target: the punishment Ephraim will receive for his mockery and insults
vehicle: handing back an insult or disgrace as if it were an object
ground: correspondence between offense and recompense (measure-for-measure)
the notion that what one sends out comes back upon oneself
fittingness and symmetry in divine judgment
posture: prophetic affirmation of lex talionis in moral realm
instances.explanation: The phrase pictures God ‘returning’ Ephraim’s own reproach to him, as if handing back what Ephraim had thrown at God or others, metaphorically portraying judgment as a just repayment of his mockery.
